searchDocs.title: Setup​
searchDocs.content: Attrify needs to be started on both server and client. Each watcher automatically determines whether it should run on server or client.

searchDocs.title: Server Script​
searchDocs.content: -- ServerScriptService/Server.server.luau local ReplicatedStorage = game:GetService("ReplicatedStorage") local Attrify = require(ReplicatedStorage.Packages.Attrify) Attrify.start()

searchDocs.title: Client Script​
searchDocs.content: -- ReplicatedFirst/Client.client.luau (or StarterPlayerScripts) local ReplicatedStorage = game:GetService("ReplicatedStorage") local Attrify = require(ReplicatedStorage.Packages.Attrify) Attrify.start()

searchDocs.title: Using Watchers​
searchDocs.content: Once attrify is started, simply add tags to your parts:  Select a part in Roblox StudioOpen the Tag Editor (View → Tag Editor)Add a tag like attr_jump_pad or attr_spinnerConfigure attributes in the Properties panel

searchDocs.title: Tag Naming​
searchDocs.content: Most watchers use the attr_ prefix for their tags:  attr_spinner - Spinner watcherattr_jump_pad - Jump Pad watcher (note: some use underscore naming)attr_coin - Coin watcher  Check the Watcher Reference for the exact tag name for each watcher.

searchDocs.title: Listening to Events​
searchDocs.content: Many watchers fire signals that you can listen to:  local Attrify = require(ReplicatedStorage.Packages.Attrify) Attrify.start() -- Listen for coin collection Attrify.Signals.CoinCollected:Connect(function(player, value, part) -- Award coins to player print(player.Name, "collected", value, "coins!") end) -- Listen for button presses Attrify.Signals.ButtonPressed:Connect(function(player, part) -- Trigger game logic print(player.Name, "pressed button:", part.Name) end)

searchDocs.title: Available Signals​
searchDocs.content: Signal	Parameters	DescriptionCoinCollected	player, value, part	Coin was collected CollectibleCollected	player, type, amount, part	Collectible was picked up PromptTriggered	player, part	Proximity prompt was triggered Clicked	player, part	Clickable part was clicked ButtonPressed	player, part	Button was touched PartBroken	part	Breakable part was destroyed

searchDocs.title: Project Structure​
searchDocs.content: Recommended project structure with attrify:  src/ ├── Server/ │ └── Entry.server.luau -- Call Attrify.start() ├── Client/ │ └── Entry.client.luau -- Call Attrify.start() └── Shared/ └── ... Packages/ └── Attrify/ -- Installed by Wally

searchDocs.title: Dependencies​
searchDocs.content: attrify depends on:  dig1t/maid - Cleanup managementdig1t/signal - Event systemdig1t/util - Utility functions  These are automatically installed by Wally.

searchDocs.title: start​
searchDocs.content: </> Attrify.start( config: Config?-- Optional configuration table ) → () Starts Attrify watchers. Call this once on both server and client. Each watcher automatically determines if it should run on server or client.

searchDocs.content: </> Attrify.setPlayerCheckpoint( player: Player ,-- The player to set checkpoint for checkpointNumber: number-- The checkpoint number to set ) → boolean-- True if checkpoint was set successfully Set player's checkpoint state (for loading from persistence). Call this when player joins to restore their saved checkpoint.

searchDocs.content: </> Attrify.spawnPlayerAtCheckpoint( player: Player ,-- The player to spawn checkpointNumber: number-- The checkpoint number to spawn at ) → boolean-- True if spawn was successful Spawn player at a specific checkpoint.

searchDocs.content: </> Attrify.getPlayerCheckpoint( player: Player -- The player to get checkpoint for ) → number?-- The current checkpoint number, or nil if not set Get player's current in-memory checkpoint (not persisted).

searchDocs.title: Quick Example​
searchDocs.content: Add the attr_coin tag to any BasePartSet attr_value attribute to 30Players touching the part will be awarded 30 coins!  That's it! No code needed for basic functionality. But if you want to react to events:  local Attrify = require(ReplicatedStorage.Packages.Attrify) Attrify.Signals.CoinCollected:Connect(function(player, value, part) print(player.Name, "collected", value, "coins!") -- Expect "Player collected 30 coins!" end)

searchDocs.title: Features​
searchDocs.content: 50 pre-built watchers for common game mechanicsZero scripting - configure everything via attributesModular - only use what you needType-safe - full Luau strict mode supportSignals - react to events in your own code

searchDocs.title: Watcher Categories​
searchDocs.content: AnimationMovementVisualCombatInteractionDoorObbySoundCollectDestructionConstraint

searchDocs.title: How It Works​
searchDocs.content: attrify uses Roblox's CollectionService to watch for tagged instances. When you add a tag like attr_jump_pad to a part, attrify automatically applies the behavior and reads configuration from the part's attributes.  [Part with "attr_jump_pad" tag] └── attr_jump_distance = 20 └── attr_cooldown = 1 └── attr_push_relative_to_object = true   The watcher reads these attributes and applies the jump pad behavior - launching players upward when they touch the part.
